reviewText: "Cold Turkey" is one of the few genuine satires in the history of American film, definitely one of the richest in casting, one of the best scored, and still very funny. So, to have it available, even in somewhat shabby form, is a blessing, mixed though it may be. That amounts to about two and three quarters of my three-star rating.The goofy premise of this movie has publicity flak Merwin Wren (Bob Newhart) convincing a tobacco magnate (Edward Everett Horton) to make a facetious offer of $25 million to any town that will give up smoking en masse for 30 days. The townspeople of Eagle Rock, Iowa, led by Rev. Clayton Brooks (Dick Van Dyke), call the bluff and take the pledge. The very human comedy that grows out of this situation is the work of Jean Stapleton, Pippa Scott, Vincent Gardenia, Barnard Hughes, Graham Jarvis, Paul Benedict, Bob & Ray (as a host of '60-ish news personalities), and the ever-delightful Judith Lowry, among a host of many more who were or would become familiar faces on sitcoms. If Norman Lear's script is a bit loopy, his direction more than compensates, drawing human comedy not only from the seasoned players but from the scores of Iowans recruited as extras. The humor is so close to the heart that it works against the rather zany climax to some extent (though the subtext is true enough: notice which character doesn't seem to be dying).The good news about this "on demand" recording is that it finally presents the movie in its original widescreen format. And that's about it. The pictorial quality is acceptable, but sometimes worn at the edges. There are about 21 unidentified chapter stops that stop nowhere in particular, but at least advance you through the movie. The sound ranges from good to abominable, and this is a tragedy. Randy Newman's score, incorporating strains of school fight songs and revival meeting favorites, is beautiful Americana, but this recording practically shreds it. The opening bars have been cut off and the movie is opens "in progress." Sometimes the soundtrack sounds so "boxey" and full of echo that you might wonder if it was recorded with a boom box situated in front of a tv set. At other times, as in the jogging scene, the track has so much distortion that it sounds like it's coming from a badly worn record.If you're as big a fan of this movie as I am, you probably have either the laserdisk or the VHS copies that were released in the early '90s. The laserdisk was mastered from a pan & scan print, but the track was digitally mastered, and the overall package, complete with about 33 chapter stops and the original trailer, is a far superior reproduction next to this dvd slop job, even if it isn't true to the original aspect ratio. If you have this release (along with Percepto's limited edition CD of the soundtrack), then you may want to keep your laserdisk player in good repair and just forget about the dvd.I truly wish I could be more positive about this release. The widescreen presentation almost makes it worthwhile, but all of its shortcomings undercut everything except the intrinsic value of the comedy itself. "Cold Turkey" and everybody associated with it deserves better.
summary: So Close, yet So Far Away

reviewText: It's a shame more people don't remember this film.  Made in 1971, it hasn't aged one bit.  It remains a devastating (and gut-bustingly funny)  commentary on addiction, greed, and industry.  How can you go wrong with a  script by Larry Gelbart (writer of several classic "M*A*S*H"  episodes), direction by Norman Lear (who brought us "All in the  Family," "Maude," "The Jeffersons," etc.), and a  cast of comic geniuses like Dick Van Dyke, Bob Newhart, Edwrad Everett  Horton, Jean Stapelton (Edith Bunker on "All in the Family"),  Vincent Gardenia, Tom Poston ("Newhart"), and Bob & Ray? You  can't.  Throw in a score which features some of Randy Newman's best songs  from his album "Sail Away," and you have one of the great film  comedies.

reviewText: "Cold Turkey" is definitely a mixed bag.  It works best as an expose of the cynicism of the tobacco industry.  It's funniest moments are it's portrayal of nicotine withdrawal notably the guy who drop-kicked the dog.  Good supporting cast notably Barnard Hughes as a surgeon whose smoking cessation puts him on the verge of a nervous breakdown and the late, great, Judith Lowry who played comical TV grannies in the Seventies as a smoking defense warden.  Lowry had another great bit in Sidney Lumet's "The Anderson Tapes".  Randy Newman contributes a particularly memorable score.  It's weak points are it's condescending attitude towards Middle America.  For the most part the characters are garish stereotypes which undermines the film's satiric ambitions.  This should come as no surprise because the film is written and directed by Norman Lear and this was his trademark in his Seventies sitcom empire.  This film is not all it could be.  If you want a better film about America's love affair with tobacco check out Jason Reitman's "Thank You For Smoking".  Nonetheless, there's enough here for a marginal recommendation.
summary: It Would Be Rated PG-13 Today For Excessive Smoking

reviewText: I remember seeing "Cold Turkey" back in the early 70's when I was but a wee lad, but even then, I found it to be very funny.  I wouldn't describe it as  laugh-out-loud funny, but a smart satire; so don't go in expecting Jim Carrey antics! Instead, you'll get some wonderful character actors (Bob Newhart, Tom Poston, Graham Jarvis, Vincent Gardenia, and Dick Van Dyke) playing some of the town's memorable inhabitants.The premise is that the Valiant Tobacco Company, in an effort to improve its image and show it's a company that "cares," decides to offer $25 million dollars to any town that can quite smoking for thirty days. The only town in the USA where all the inhabitants have signed a binding pledge is Eagle Rock, Iowa. The tobacco company, taken aback that a town would actually accept their offer, goes into damage control mode as they attempt to foil the townspeople's' efforts.There are so many great performances, it's hard for me to pick just one. But the one that comes to mind first is that of the late Graham Jarvis as Amos Bush, President of the Christopher Mott Society. His introduction to the society's very special guest, Rear Admiral Nelson Steinschweiker, is priceless!The movie was written and directed by Norman Lear back in 1971, just before "All in the Family" was unleashed. And I can't forget the wonderful score by Randy Newman. It complements the small town atmosphere so vividly portrayed on screen. If the DVD and the movie soundtrack ever sees the light of day, I'll be first in line to make my purchase! Truly one of my all time favorite movies.

reviewText: A hidden gem from the early 70's, funnier by far than all the TV sitcoms and "comedy" films rleased week after week. My favorite scene among many fine ones is where town-drunk Tom Poston delivers a hiarious, whacked-out anatomy lesson describing how if he stops smoking it will inevitably lead to his head falling off. So the civic leaders convince him to leave town for a while, at least until they win their money.  With all Norman Lear's Hollywood clout you'd think he'd have convinced Universal to release it on DVD by now. I think there's a big-enough niche market waiting for it to justify its release.
summary: I've gone "Cold Turkey" DVD-less long enough

reviewText: I saw this movie several times in the 80's when it ran repeatedly on a local station over one summer. I thought it was going to be dumb, but it turned out to be one of the most intelligently made comedies/satires ever. It's not obvious "in-your-face" antics like stuff you'll see today, but layer upon layer of subtleties. By the end of the summer we were dropping everything not to miss the next showing. This is a classic, and it gets better with repeated viewings. With all the junk out there, why isn't this out on DVD?
summary: I really want this one to come out on DVD!

reviewText: Norman Lear got his feet wet making this movie and "discovered" Jean Stapleton who was so little known at the time, she did not even get mentioned on the cover.  "Her earliest association with producer-director Norman Lear occurred in the 1969 theatrical feature Cold Turkey, in which she played a neurotic housewife named Edith. When Lear began assembling the cast for his upcoming TV sitcom All in the Family, he immediately thought of Stapleton for the role of slow-witted, strident, essentially kindhearted Bronx housewife Edith Bunker." Answers.com  With a scene near the end where I can once again see my late mother cheering "the President", I enjoy this comedy.

reviewText: lucky seven for those of us who fondly recall this underappreciated satire.  Keep in mind that it was only in 1966 that Congress first required ciagarette manufactureres to place specific warning labels on cigarette packs and that the last cigarette commercial (for Virginia Slims) was broadcast on "The Tonight Show" at one minute to midnight on January 1, 1971.  While there were those who were worried that the lost of ad revenue would destroy network television (which seemed like a good idea at the time), the larger question was how cigarette companies would seek to market their product.In "Cold Turkey" the idea is advanced by Merwin Wren (Bob Newhart), an advertising executive who convinces the Valiant Tobacco Company to offer $25 million to any town that can stop smoking for thirty days.  The idea is that the offer will generate free publicity but that no town in American would ever be able to successfully go cold turkey.  But the 4,006 heavy smokers of Eagle Rock, Iowa take up the challenge, led by the thought of all that money and the persuasive efforts of The Reverend Clayton Brooks (Dick Van Dyke), of the Eagle Rock Community Church.  The town had been trying to woo back the military, hoping the return of the military industrial complex would help the local cash flow, but that has not panned out.This film, co-written and directed by Norman Lear, on the cusp of remaking television with "All in the Family," falls into three acts.  In the first Reverend Brooks convinces the townspeople to take the pledge, while in the second the members of the community deal with not being able to smoke any more (substituting sex seemed like such a good idea at the time).  The climax of the film comes as it looks like Eagle Rock might actually be able to do it and Merwin Wren has to pull out all the stops to make sure that does not happen.  There are plenty of laughs and while you have to feel "Cold Turkey" falls short of its true satirical potential, it is still worthy tracking down and checking out.In many ways "Cold Turkey" is the impoverished cousin of "It's a Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad World," with a host of familiar faces such as Tom Poston, Vincent Gardenia, Jean Stapleton, Barnard Hughes, Graham Jarvis, and Edward Everett Horton.  The comedy team of Bob (Elliott) and Ray (Goulding) appear in multiple roles of "familiar" Names.  Bob is Hugh Upson, David Chetley, and Sandy Van Andy, while Ray plays Walter Chronic, Paul Hardly, and Arthur Lordly (think about it for a while and if you are my age you should get most of those).  Add to the mix Randy Newman's first film score, which opens with his song "He Gives Us all His Love."What brought this movie back to mind was the decision of Hollywood to change the case at the heart of John Grisham's novel "Runaway Jury" from a tobacco case to a gun case.  The reasoning was that Hollywood had already done a "cigarette" more with "The Insider," and, as we all know, Hollywood never repeats an idea and companies only pay to have products placed in movies not to have them not placed in movies.  However, even a faithful adaptation of Grisham's novel would not be as brutal an indictment of the tobacco industry as "Cold Turkey."  For that matter it has a pretty cynical take on small town Americana as well.  Of course, in the end the joke is on the people of Eagle Rock, and, by extension, the rest of us.
summary: A forgotten satire on the tobacco industry from Norman Lear

reviewText: Like so many others, until recently, I had only the vaguest memories of this early Norman Lear production. Lear is known today as the hard-hitting dramatist who enjoyed fame with cutting edge tv series like "All In The Family" and "Maude".This film project reflects many of the themes he would consistently tackle as a tv producer/writer: Taking stabs at the ruthlessness of corporations, arrogance and idiocy of what was then considered small-town America, the pompous vanity of people who seek out public office, and the desperate avarice that often blinds everything and everyone regardless of ideology or position.Van Dyke portrays Reverend Clayton Brooks, one of several clergymen posted to a small rural town in Iowa. A community that has seen its better days when the Air Force had a base stationed within the town limits. However, that was many years ago and with their withdrawal, Eagle Rock has deteriorated; likely to suffer a slow lingering passage into history. The good reverend can see the handwriting on the wall and attempts to abandon ship by requesting a transfer to the bigger stage of Detroit. Mind you this was 1971 - and the Motor City was at its apex of American preeminence. But the church bishop insists that his performance in Eagle Rock will determine his own destiny. Brooks is less than enthused.Simultaneously, a marketing executive played by the always dependable Bob Newhart has embarked on an ambitious plan to save the muddied reputation of his client - a cigarette manufacturer. How? By offering a prize of $25 million dollars (in 2011 that would be the equivalent of $200 million) to any town or city that can verifiably give up all forms of tobacco for thirty days. Given his supreme confidence that this is in fact impossible, Newhart convinces the chairman of the board to offer the money in order to buy the public's good will, comparing the gimmick to the oft-forgotten history of another beneficiary of humanity's seeming addiction to death - Alfred Nobel and his Peace Prize.These two men and their respective end-goals meet in 'Cold Turkey'.What follows is a fairly brutal dissection of 1970's small-town America and it's stereotyped residents.No hero or heroics - just a farcical study of addiction, mob mentality, and greed - both personal and collective. This dark comedy is hard-edged and played mainly for the various ways the residents are caught attempting to cheat and/or deal with tobacco withdrawal.

reviewText: A movie demonstrates comic talent when you laugh during the first viewing. A movie demonstrates comic genius when you're laughing during the thirty-first viewing. After watching it four times on TV and at least once a year since the first 1989 video release, I am still holding my sides.The worst thing about Hollywood comedies is the producers' insistence on padding nearly every one with boring, unfunny garbage - there has to be a "life lesson", an annoying romance, or scenes where egotistical turds like Chevy Chase or Eddie Murphy force us to watch their "acting chops", or, God help us, their singing (even Animal House had the stupid Karen Allen love triangle). Here Lear and Yorkin refuse to include any of that stuff. It starts out absurd, but the absurdity then builds and builds until you arrive at the most wonderfully insane climax in motion picture history.The problems created by movie star egos are avoided here by not casting any movie stars. Instead, baby boomers will enjoy seeing a who's who of 1960's and 1970's television comedy including Dick Van Dyke, Bob Newhart, Tom Poston, Jean Stapleton, Vincent Gardenia, Bob Elliot, Ray Goulding and especially Judith Lowry. It even has the guy (EEN) who narrated "Fractured Fairy Tales" from the Bullwinkle show in the role of silent Hiram Grayson.Amazon deserves applause of course for including this in its "homemade DVD" program. It has the kind of limitations you might expect, with a small windowboxed image and a lot of echo when there is more than one voice on the soundtrack. I haven't been able to find out what was used as source material, but it wasn't the answer print, since the first (mumbled) ERCC rendition of "O God Our Help in Ages Past" is still missing. There are literally no extras of any kind. Definitely buy it if you don't have it at all, but if you have a tape, this doesn't improve on it much.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I've LOVED this movie ever since seeing it in the theater as a kid and like so many others waited years for the widescreen DVD release. What a disappointment. GREAT movie -- awful sound and picture.The sound has that watery wobbly hollow sound as if they used a bitrate of about 2. The wonderful Randy Newman score sounds like it's being performed underwater.The picture? It's widescreen but not anamorphic so it doesn't fill up the tv screen. Also it looks flat -- not enough contrast and not very colorful. I dunno someone somewhere must not like this movie and went to great lengths to make it the worst DVD transfer ever. That's the only way it could turn out this bad.On the brighter side Turner Classic Movies FINALLY ran Cold Turkey once a few months ago. The widescreen picture looked great and the audio was a LOT better but still a little hollow sounding in a few places.Why doesn't this great satire get the DVD transfer it deserves? Thanks for listening.
summary: One of my all time faves BUT the sound (and picture) are messed up

reviewText: I recently picked this up as I am a big fan of Dick Van Dyke and Bob Newhart...and while I wasn't nearly as happy with this movie as "Fitzwilly" also purchased at the same time I still  feel its worth the $15 to have on DVD R and its certainly a reasonable print.  Any time you get real "topical"  in your art you run the risk  of placing the project a bit in a time capsule and I'm afraid much of this film comes across as quite  dated due to it trying to be so  current and cutting edge in its day.  This isn't to say it  doesn't still ring true in many ways or offer a good  laugh here and there it just dates  itself and does it often. If you are looking for some old school Dick Van Dyke I'd recommend Fitzwilly or Chitty Chitty Bang Bang ....that is if you've tired of his classic TV series which is available on beautifully restored DVD with so  many bonus features!
summary: DVD R looks pretty good  and at $15 its good  value for money...

reviewText: This is one of my favorite movies.  It will appeal to people of all ages, but those in the 65+ age group will enjoy it the most.  The movie is a story about a small Iowa town's successful campaign to win a $25 million prize by having every resident give up smoking for a month.  It features great acting by Dick Van Dyke, Bob Newhart, Pippa Scott and Tom Poston.  Comedians Bob and Ray play a variety of cameo roles based on some of the radio and TV personalities of the 1970s.  There's even a brief appearance by President Nixon. You'll also recognize several other actors who later became very popular in TV sitcoms. If you're a former or current smoker you will appreciate the efforts of the town's residents to meet the no smoking challenge.  If nothing else, you'll get lots of laughs while watching the movie.

reviewText: This is a great comedy. There is some subtle humor that I wonder if anyone else picked up on. For example, Ray Goulding's famous newsman character "Walter Chronic" (an obvious satire of Walter Chronkite) is seen arriving on the scene in the hospital where a nicotine-starved doctor is about to perform heart surgery on a patient. As "Walter Chronic" enters, he pauses in a double doorway while everyone gasps, "Walter Chronic is here! Walter Chronic is here!", and a circular fluorescent ceiling lamp can be seen behind him perfectly positioned over his head like a halo!  Whoever is not putting this out on DVD is losing a lot of money!

reviewText: This is a funny and charming film with a great cast and witty politically-aimed subtext of characters, attitudes and circumstance expressed that has fresh resonance today.  Starring Dick Van Dyke and featuring Bob Newhart, Pippa Scott, Tom Poston, comedy team Bob & Ray and even venerated 1930's and 40's character actor Edward Everett Horton, there are also other wonderful actors aboard such as Jean Stapleton, Bernard Hughes, Vincent Gardenia and many others in supporting roles.The film story involves a small, depressed midwestern town which, having lost it's former Air Force Base and attendant civilian employment, jumps at the chance to win 25 million dollars cynically offered by a tobacco company's sales advisor (Newhart) as a PR gag to any town that can give up smoking for one month.  They are rallied by the town's minister (Van Dyke) and the barber/mayor (Gardenia) to go for the prize, and a small world of comic unrest ensues.This film has a number of milestones going for it— among them, Norman Lear's feature directorial debut, Randy Newman's first film score, Pippa Scott's cinematic return, and Edward Everett Horton's final film role.Not enthusiastically released by it's studio in 1971, and subsequently sold to the home market only in pan-and-scan versions on VHS and Laser Disc, this is, I believe, the first time it has been available on DVD.Unfortunately, this made-to-order-by-request DVD from Amazon is technically flawed.  The print, while full wide screen, is dark and a bit dirty in places.  Much worse is the sound track, which consists of a faux stereo re-formatting that is out-of-phase, causing any extended sound efx, sound ambiences, and most of the music scoring to sound as though they were coming out of a garden hose.  Adding injury to insult, this out-of-phase track is mid-panned and duplicated on both channels, making it impossibleto even listen to one clear mono track from either channel.And so, "Cold Turkey" has again regrettably and undeservedly gotten another bad release.  Hopefully, Amazon will note my above remarks and remedy the situation with whomever unskilled bozo techs were subcontracted to make this DVD.  Considerthis my sincere appeal to order the simple tech fixes necessary to present this show as it deserves to be seen.  And if you read this, Mr. Lear, please follow suit and complain loudly.  Your film is a worthwhile little gem.  Thank you,  Tom P. Bullock

reviewText: Well before smoking was the demon it is now, this film dared to take on Big Tobacco in the historically best way possible - by laughing at it.  Publicity man Merwin Wren (Bob Newhart in one of his truly classic "Angry Little Man" performances) suggests that the tobacco companies put up 25 million dollars, to be awarded to the first town that can quit smoking for 30 days.  A classic false deal, Wren explains, because what town could successfully quit smoking for a full 30 days?Eagle Rock, Iowa.  Under the inspiration of Rev. Clayton Brooks (Dick Van Dyke), the town sees the offer as a way to get back on its feet, and for such a little bit of sacrifice. Yeah, right...The town becomes a center of media interest, not to mention great consternation to the tobacco companies.  What was supposed to be a PR campaign dedicated to make people think they actually want people to stop smoking, this little town is ACTUALLY convincing people to stop smoking.The tension (literal and figurative) builds until the very last minute of the 30-day deadline, when a tampered-with clock and an aerial drop of smokes threaten the work Eagle Rock has done.  And if they ever figure out the legal mess and put the film out on DVD, you can see how it all ends up.The film attacks so many targets simultaneously, and doesn't miss once.  The smoking culture, both users and manufacturers get it, as does the news industry.  Like so many great satires, it remains relevant today.  The majority of the anti-smoking ads that run today are paid for by the tobacco companies, albeit as a result of the massive lawsuits laid against them in recent years. And as much as they put educational materials up on their sites, only a rank boob would think they actually want people to stop smoking.Bob and Ray play several parts in the film, including Ray Goulding as Walter Chronic, the grand old man of news, whose name is spoken wirth the same reverance as Ed Sullivan's in Bye Bye Birdie.Even this early in his career, Randy Newman delivers a score and song (He Sends us All His Love) that will stay with you.  Not a bad note in the movie.
summary: Prescient, incisive, cruel and friggin' hilarious

After watching it four times on TV and at least once a year since getting the tape in 1989, I am still holding my sides.The worst thing about Hollywood comedies is the filmmakers' insistence on padding nearly every one with boring, unfunny garbage - there has to be a "life lesson", or an annoying romance, or scenes where egotistical turds like Chevy Chase or Eddie Murphy force us to watch their "acting chops", or, God help us, their singing (even Animal House had the stupid Karen Allen love triangle). This movie refuses to include any of that stuff. It starts out absurd, but the absurdity then builds and builds until you arrive at the most wonderfully insane climax in motion picture history.The problems created by movie star egos are avoided here by not casting any movie stars. Instead, baby boomers may enjoy seeing a who's who of 1960's and 1970's television comedy including Dick Van Dyke, Bob Newhart, Tom Poston, Jean Stapleton, Vincent Gardenia, Bob Elliot, Ray Goulding and especially Judith Lowry. reviewText: I love this film, so my rating is really just a review of the DVD.  Despite the fact that the case says "full screen", this movie is presented as mentioned on here in what I presume is 1:85/1.  While it doesn't present a HUGE improvement over the old VHS framing, it does allow you to see the credits, which the previous version did not.  The movie doesn't appear to have been restored in any meaningful way, but it is much clearer than the VHS release.  I suspect that the production values were never especially sophisticated, so I didn't expect it to look like a classic Hollywood film.  I don't have the laserdisc release so I don't know if this is simply a DVD issue of that transfer.  While I would much rather have a pressed commercial DVD release, I'm glad to finally have this movie on DVD and can now retired my old videotape to the trash.
Title: N/A
